title: Week 2: January 5–11 - Moses 1; Abraham 3
content:
# Come, Follow Me 2026: Week 2 (January 5–11)  
**Moses 1; Abraham 3**

## Week Overview
What if the Lord revealed your true identity before answering your deepest questions about creation? That's exactly what happened to Moses when he asked, “Be merciful unto thy servant, O God, and tell me concerning this earth, and the inhabitants thereof, and also the heavens” (Moses 1:36). This vision, along with Abraham's, frames the Old Testament by answering: Who is God? Who are we? What is God’s work, and what is our place in it?

## Key Scripture Moments
Here's the remarkable moment when God declares Moses's divine worth: “thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten” (Moses 1:6). Notice what happens next—Satan counters with doubt: “Moses, son of man, worship me” (Moses 1:12). Then, the dramatic turning point: Moses calls on God and sees Satan's defeat (Moses 1:20–22, 26). Finally, after glimpsing endless worlds, Moses hears God's purpose: “For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man” (Moses 1:39).

## Hidden Connections
These visions connect ancient seers: Like Moses seeing God's creations (Moses 1:27–39), Abraham beholds premortal intelligences chosen for earth's proving (Abraham 3:22–28). Both reveal our premortal roots—“before the world was” (Abraham 3:22)—echoing Moses's plea for earth's inhabitants (Moses 1:36). Satan’s counterfeit power in Moses 1:13–18 mimics God's true authority, a pattern solved by invoking “the name of the Only Begotten” (Moses 1:25).

## Pattern Discovery
Notice this pattern across prophets: God affirms identity first—Moses as “son of man” yet like His Son (Moses 1:4, 6)—before Satan attacks it (Moses 1:12). Abraham sees noble spirits, including “one among the selves” like Jesus, prepared “to make an earth” and “prove them herewith” (Abraham 3:24–25). This repeats: divine worth precedes temptation and purpose, linking Moses's resistance (Moses 1:13, 15, 18, 20–22, 26) to our premortal choices.

## Simple Questions
1. In Moses 1:4, 6 and 1:12, how do God's words differ from Satan's—what does this teach about your identity?  
2. What helped Moses overcome in Moses 1:24–26—how can that strengthen your testimony?  
3. Why does Moses ask “why these things are so” after the vision (Moses 1:30)—what's God's answer in 1:31–39?  
4. In Abraham 3:24–26, what truths about yourself and Jesus Christ stand out?  
5. How does knowing you lived “before the world was” (Abraham 3:22) change daily decisions?  
6. What's the difference between immortality and eternal life (Moses 1:39; Topics and Questions, “Eternal Life”)?

## One Big Idea
God’s work and glory is “to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man” (Moses 1:39). Revealed to Moses after his identity affirmation, this principle from Joseph Smith's inspired translation reframes creation—not random, but purposeful for our eternal growth. Abraham's vision adds premortal context: We were spirits chosen to “prove” ourselves through obedience (Abraham 3:25).

## Living It
Compare God's message in Moses 1:4 with Satan's in 1:12 at family dinner—how does this guide treating yourself and others as children of God? When tempted, act out Moses's steps: pray, command in Christ's name, and seek help (Moses 1:13–26). List choices flowing from your divine identity, as it “affects almost every decision you will ever make” (“Choices for Eternity”).

## Faith Builder
President Russell M. Nelson taught, “If the Lord were speaking to you directly, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity” (“Choices for Eternity” [worldwide devotional for young adults, May 2022], Gospel Library). Echoing Moses 1:4, 6, he urges knowing “the truth about who you are” first. These latter-day words confirm ancient visions, inviting us to let this truth shape our path to eternal life. I cherish how the Spirit witnesses this divine heritage in my own life.
